member.name: F:PX.Data.PXDatabaseAccessProvider.Definition._EstimatedRolesInGraphRowsCount
member.summary: Estimated number of rows in the DB table.
member.remarks: The median amount of rows in the RolesInGraph DB table calced over 200 DBs from support cases is about 30 400 rows, the average amount is about 64 096 rows The median amount of rows in the RolesInGraph DB table calced over several versions of SalesDemo is about 12 400 rows. The estimated capacity is 2^14, a power of two (since the size of dynamic lists starts with 4 and is doubled on resize, so it will reach this number after some resizes anyway) It is not too big but can store data for a median Sales Demo and after one resize for the median amount calced from the actual user data.

member.name: T:PX.Data.PXSiteMapNodeSelectorAttribute
member.summary: The attribute that is added to the field that stores the screen ID and is used to display the site map location.
member.remarks: PXSiteMapNodeSelector shows the list of screens, but does not contain Workspace and Category columns in the selector. If you need to display these columns, add a reference to the PX.Web.UI.Frameset namespace and use the SiteMapSelectorAttribute attribute.

code.title: Example
code.description: The following example shows the use of the attribute.

example.code:
#region ScreenID public abstract class screenID : PX.Data.BQL.BqlString.Field<screenID> { }
[PXDBString(8, IsFixed = true, InputMask = "CC.CC.CC.CC")] [PXDefault] [PXUIField(DisplayName = "Screen Name", Visibility = PXUIVisibility.SelectorVisible)] [PXSiteMapNodeSelector] public virtual string ScreenID { get; set; } #endregion

code.title: Example2
code.description: You should use the PXSelector control in the corresponding ASPX page, as shown in the following code example.

example.code: <px:PXSelector ID="edScreen" runat="server" DataField="ScreenID" DisplayMode="Text" FilterByAllFields="true" CommitChanges="True" />

member.name: M:PX.Data.AutomapperExtensions.ForCtorParamMatching``3(AutoMapper.IMappingExpression{``0,``1},System.Linq.Expressions.Expression{System.Func{``1,``2}},System.Action{AutoMapper.ICtorParamConfigurationExpression{``0}})
member.summary: Works similar to , but allows you to define parameter name using expression instead of hardcoded string.

member.name: T:PX.Data.Aggregate`1
member.summary: A wrapper clause for the GroupBy clauses and aggregation functions.
member.typeparam: The GroupBy class or aggregation function.

code.title: Example
code.description: The following BQL statement groups the records of the Table table by the Table.field1 field and calculates the sums of the Table.field2 field in each group.

example.code: PXSelectGroupBy<Table, Aggregate<GroupBy<Table.field1, Sum<Table.field2>>>>

code.title: Example2
code.description: This is translated into the following SQL code.

example.code: SELECT Table.Field1, SUM(Table.Field2), [MAX(Table.Field) or NULL for other fields] FROM Table GROUP BY Table.Field1

member.name: T:PX.Data.Aggregate`2
member.summary: A wrapper clause for the GroupBy clauses and aggregation functions. It also supports the result filtering by using the clause.
member.typeparam: The GroupBy class or aggregation function.
The filtering condition for the result.
member.example: PXSelectGroupBy<Detail, Aggregate<GroupBy<Detail.docType, GroupBy<Detail.documentID, Sum<Detail.qty>>>, Having<Detail.qty.Summarized.IsGreaterEqual<Zero>>>> The following BQL statement groups the records of the Detail table by the Detail.docType and Detail.documentID fields, calculates the sums of the Detail.qty field in each group, and displays only those groups for which these sums are positive. Note that the Having clause requires parameters in FBQL format.

member.name: T:PX.Data.Having`1
member.summary: The class that is used to filter the results of an aggregated query. The class corresponds to the HAVING SQL clause.
member.typeparam: The filtering condition for the aggregated result.
member.example: PXSelectGroupBy<Detail, Aggregate<GroupBy<Detail.docType, GroupBy<Detail.documentID, Sum<Detail.qty>>>, Having<Detail.qty.Summarized.IsGreaterEqual<Zero>>>> This BQL statement groups records of the Detail table by the Detail.docType and Detail.documentID fields, calculates the sums of the Detail.qty field in each group, and displays only those groups that have these sums positive. Note that the Having clause requires parameters in FBQL format.

member.name: T:PX.Data.Sum`1
member.summary: Returns the sum of all Field values in a group. Equivalent to SQL function SUM.
member.typeparam: The field the function is applied to.

code.title: Example
code.description: The following BQL statement groups Table records by the Table1.field1 field and calculates sums of the Table1.field2 field in each group. The corresponding SQL query is given below.

example.code: PXSelectGroupBy<Table1, Aggregate<GroupBy<Table1.field1, Sum<Table1.field2>>>> records;
SELECT Table1.Field1, SUM(Table1.Field2), [MAX(Table1.Field) or NULL for other fields] FROM Table1 GROUP BY Table1.Field1

member.name: T:PX.Data.Sum`2
member.summary: Returns the sum of all Field values in a group and continues the aggregation clause with NextAggregate. Equivalent to SQL function SUM.
member.typeparam: The field the function is applied to.
The next GroupBy clause or aggregate function.

code.title: Example
code.description: The code below shows a data view that groups data records by one column.

example.code: PXSelectGroupBy<Table1, Aggregate<Sum<Table1.field1, Sum<Table1.field2, GroupBy<Table1.field3>>>>> records;
SELECT SUM(Table1.Field1), SUM(Table1.Field2), Table.Field3, [MAX(Table1.Field) or NULL for other fields] FROM Table1 GROUP BY Table.Field3

member.name: T:PX.Data.Sum2`1
member.summary: Returns the sum of all Expression values in a group. Equivalent to SQL function SUM.
member.typeparam: The expression operand the function is applied to.

code.title: Example
code.description: The following BQL statement groups Table records by the Table1.field1 field and calculates sums of the expressions in each group. The corresponding SQL query is given below.

example.code: PXSelectGroupBy<Table1, Aggregate<GroupBy<Table1.field1, Sum<Mult<Table1.field2, Table1.field3>>>>> records;
SELECT Table1.Field1, [MAX(Table1.Field) or NULL for other fields], SUM(Table1.Field2 * Table1.Field3) FROM Table1 GROUP BY Table1.Field1

member.name: T:PX.Data.Sum2`2
member.summary: Returns the sum of all Expression values in a group. Equivalent to SQL function SUM.
member.typeparam: The expression operand the function is applied to.

code.title: Example
code.description: The following BQL statement groups Table records by the Table1.field1 field and calculates sums of the expressions in each group. The corresponding SQL query is given below.

example.code: PXSelectGroupBy<Table1, Aggregate<GroupBy<Table1.field1, Sum<Mult<Table1.field2, Table1.field3>>>>> records;
SELECT Table1.Field1, [MAX(Table1.Field) or NULL for other fields], SUM(Table1.Field2 * Table1.Field3) FROM Table1 GROUP BY Table1.Field1

member.name: T:PX.Data.Avg`1
member.summary: Returns the average of the values of Field in a group. Equivalent to SQL function AVG.
member.typeparam: The field the function is applied to.

code.title: Example
code.description: The following BQL statement groups Table records by the Table1.field1 field and calculates average values of the Table1.field2 field in each group. The corresponding SQL query is given below.

example.code: PXSelectGroupBy<Table1, Aggregate<GroupBy<Table1.field1, Avg<Table1.field2>>>> records;
SELECT Table1.Field1, AVG(Table1.Field2), [MAX(Table1.Field) or NULL for other fields] FROM Table1 GROUP BY Table1.Field1

code.title: Example
code.description: The following BQL statement groups Table records by the Table1.field1 field and calculates sums of the Table1.field2 field in each group. The corresponding SQL query is given below.

example.code: PXSelectGroupBy<Table1, Aggregate<GroupBy<Table1.field1, Sum<Table1.field2>>>> records;
SELECT Table1.Field1, SUM(Table1.Field2), [MAX(Table1.Field) or NULL for other fields] FROM Table1 GROUP BY Table1.Field1

member.name: T:PX.Data.Count
member.summary: Counts the number of items in a group if a GroupBy clause is specified, or the total number of records in the result set otherwise. Could also be used in the clause.

remarks.para: In the corresponding SQL representation, the class is represented by COUNT(*), which is added to the list of selected columns. You access the calculated value through the RowCount property of the PXResult<> type.

code.title: Example
code.description: The code below shows how to use Count in BQL and the corresponding SQL query.

example.code: SELECT [MAX(Table1.Field) or NULL for all fields defined in the Table DAC], COUNT(*) FROM Table1

member.name: T:PX.Data.Count`1
member.summary: Counts distinct values of the specified field in a group. Equivalent to SQL function COUNT DISTINCT.
member.typeparam: The field whose distinct values are counted.
member.remarks: You access the calculated value through the RowCount property of the PXResult<> type. Note that you should use only one Count<> function in a BQL query, because you won't be able to access other such counted values.

code.title: Example
code.description: The code below shows how to use Count in BQL and the corresponding SQL query.

example.code: SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT Table1.Field2), [MAX(Table1.Field) or NULL for all other fields defined in the Table DAC] FROM Table1 GROUP BY Table1.Field1

member.name: T:PX.Data.CountCalc`1
member.summary: Calculates the number of the child data records and assigns it to the specified parent data record field.
member.typeparam: The field of the parent data record.
member.remarks: This class is used as aggregation formula in the PXFormula and PXUnboundFormula attributes to compute the parent data record field from the child data record fields. The expression that is calculated for each child data record is set in the first constructor parameter in the attributes.

example.code: [PXFormula(null, typeof(CountCalc<ARSalesPerTran.refCntr>))] public virtual Decimal? CuryTranAmt { get; set; }

member.name: T:PX.Data.And`1
member.summary: Appends a unary operator to a conditional expression via logical "and".
member.typeparam: The unary conditional expression, Not, Where, Where2, or Match

code.title: Example
code.description: The code below shows a data view and the corresponding SQL query.

example.code: SELECT * FROM Table1 WHERE ( Table1.Field1 IS NOT NULL AND NOT ( Table1.Field2 = 0 ) )

member.name: T:PX.Data.And2`2
member.summary: Appends a unary operator to a conditional expression via logical "and" and continues the chain of conditions.
member.typeparam: The unary conditional expression, Not, Where, Where2, or Match
The next conditional expression, And, And2, Or, or Or2 class.

code.title: Example
code.description: The code below iterates over Tax data records selected by a read-only data view. The second code sample shows the SQL query corresponding to the data view.

example.code: foreach (PXResult<Tax, TaxRev> record in PXSelectReadonly2<Tax, LeftJoin<TaxRev, On<TaxRev.taxID, Equal<Tax.taxID>, And<TaxRev.outdated, Equal<False>, And2<Where<TaxRev.taxType, Equal<TaxType.purchase>, And<Tax.reverseTax, Equal<False>, Or<TaxRev.taxType, Equal<TaxType.sales>>>>>, And<Current<APRegister.docDate>, Between<TaxRev.startDate, TaxRev.endDate>>>>>>.Select(this)) { ... }

SELECT * FROM Tax LEFT JOIN TaxRev ON ( TaxRev.TaxID = Tax.TaxID AND TaxRev.Outdated = CONVERT(bit, 0) AND ( TaxRev.TaxType = "P" AND Tax.ReverseTax = CONVERT(bit, 0) OR TaxRev.TaxType = "S") AND [current APRegister.DocDate value] BETWEEN TaxRev.StartDate AND TaxRev.EndDate )

member.name: T:PX.Data.And`2
member.summary: Appends a single condition to a conditional expression via logical "and".
member.typeparam: The compared operand.
The comparison operator.

code.title: Example
code.description: The following expression selects all records that are not equal to NULL from Table1 -> Filed1 along with the records from Table -> Field2 that are greater than those fetched from the Field1. The following expression will be translated into a SQL query, an example of which is given below.

example.code: SELECT * FROM Table1 WHERE ( Table1.Field1 IS NOT NULL AND Table1.Field2 > Table1.Field1)

member.name: T:PX.Data.And`3
member.summary: Appends a single condition to a conditional expression via logical "and" and continues the chain of conditions.
member.typeparam: The compared operand.
The comparison operator.
The next conditional expression, And, And2, Or, or Or2 class.

code.title: Example
code.description: The code below shows a data view and the corresponding SQL query.

example.code: PXSelect<Table1, Where<Table1.field1, IsNotNull, And<Table1.field2, Greater<Table1.field1>, Or<Table1.field1, IsNull>>>> records;
SELECT * FROM Table1 WHERE ( Table1.Field1 IS NOT NULL AND Table1.Field2 > Table1.Field1 OR Table1.Field1 IS NULL )

member.name: T:PX.Data.Or`1
member.summary: Appends a unary operator to a conditional expression via logical "or".
member.typeparam: The unary conditional expression Not, Where, Where2, or Match

code.title: Example
code.description: The code below shows a data view and the corresponding SQL query.

example.code: SELECT * FROM Table1 WHERE ( Table1.Field1 IS NULL OR NOT ( Table1.Field1 = 0 ) )

member.name: T:PX.Data.Or2`2
member.summary: Appends a unary operator to a conditional expression via logical "or" and continues the chain of conditions.
member.typeparam: The unary conditional expression Not, Where, Where2, or Match
The next conditional expression, And, And2, Or, or Or2 class.

code.title: Example
code.description: The code below shows a data view and the corresponding SQL query.

example.code: PXSelect<Table1, Where<Table1.field1, IsNull, Or2<Where<Table1.field1, Equal<Zero>, And<Table1.field2, IsNotNull>>, Or<Table1.field1, Greater<Zero>>>>> records;
SELECT * FROM Table1 WHERE ( Table1.Field1 IS NULL OR ( Table1.Field1 = 0 AND Table1.Field2 IS NOT NULL ) OR Table1.Field1 > 0 )

member.name: T:PX.Data.Or`2
member.summary: Appends a single condition to a conditional expression via logical "or".
member.typeparam: The compared operand.
The comparison operator.

code.title: Example
code.description: The code below shows a data view and the corresponding SQL query.

example.code: SELECT * FROM Table1 WHERE ( Table1.Field1 IS NULL OR Table1.Field1 = 0 )

member.name: T:PX.Data.Or`3
member.summary: Appends a single condition to a conditional expression via logical "or" and continues the chain of conditions.
member.typeparam: The compared operand.
The comparison operator.
The next conditional expression, And, And2, Or, or Or2 class.

code.title: Example
code.description: The code below shows a data view and the corresponding SQL query.

example.code: PXSelect<Table1, Where<Table1.field1, IsNull, Or<Table1.field1, Equal<Zero>, Or<Table1.field1, Greater<Table1.field2>>>>> records;
SELECT * FROM Table1 WHERE ( Table1.Field1 IS NULL OR Table1.Field1 = 0 OR Table1.Field1 > Table1.Field2 )

member.summary: Checks if the preceding field is null. Equivalent to SQL operator IS NULL.

member.summary: Checks if the preceding field is not null. Results in true for data records with this field containing a value. Equivalent to SQL operator IS NOT NULL.

member.name: T:PX.Data.BQL.BqlAggregatedOperand`2.IsIn`1
member.summary: Checks if the preceding operand matches any value in the array returned by the operand that should be the Required or Optional BQL parameter with a specified field name. The condition is true if the preceding operand is equal to a value from the array. Equivalent to the SQL operator IN. The In operator is used to replace multiple OR conditions in a BQL statement.

member.name: T:PX.Data.BQL.BqlAggregatedOperand`2.IsNotIn`1
member.summary: Checks if the preceding operand does not match any value in the array returned by the operand that should be the Required or Optional BQL parameter with a specified field name. The condition is true if the array does not contain a value that is equal to the preceding operand. Equivalent to SQL operator NOT IN.

member.name: T:PX.Data.BQL.BqlAggregatedOperand`2.IsIn`2
member.summary: Checks if the specified field value matches any value in the list of constants defined by the operand. The condition is true if the field value is equal to a value from the list.

member.name: T:PX.Data.BQL.BqlAggregatedOperand`2.IsNotIn`2
member.summary: Checks if the specified field value does not match a value in the list of constants defined by the operand. The condition is true if the field value is not present in the list.

member.name: T:PX.Data.BQL.BqlAggregatedOperand`2.IsInSequence`1
member.summary: Checks if the specified field value matches any value in the list of constants defined by the operand. The condition is true if the field value is equal to a value from the list.

member.name: T:PX.Data.BQL.BqlAggregatedOperand`2.IsNotInSequence`1
member.summary: Checks if the specified field value does not match a value in the list of constants defined by the operand. The condition is true if the field value is not present in the list.

member.summary: The default value will not be inserted if NULL was passed to the parameter.

member.name: T:PX.Data.BQL.BqlField`2.AsOptional
member.summary: Inserts the Current property value of the cache or the value explicitly passed to the Select() method. In the latter case, the parameter causes raising of the FieldUpdating event for the specified field (which can modify or substitute the value). If the null value is passed or the Current property is null, the default value of the field is inserted.

member.summary: Checks if the value of the preceding operand falls between the values of and . Equivalent to SQL operator BETWEEN.

member.summary: Checks if the value of the preceding operand does not fall between the values of and . Equivalent to SQL operator NOT BETWEEN.

member.name: T:PX.Data.BQL.BqlOperand`2.IsNotNull
member.summary: Checks if the preceding field is not null. Results in true for data records with this field containing a value. Equivalent to SQL operator IS NOT NULL.

member.name: T:PX.Data.BQL.BqlOperand`2.IsInSubselect`1
member.summary: Checks if the preceding operand matches any value in the results of the Search-based statement that is defined by the operand. The condition is true if the preceding operand is equal to a value from the result set. Equivalent to SQL statement IN(SELECT FROM ).

member.name: T:PX.Data.BQL.BqlOperand`2.IsNotInSubselect`1
member.summary: Checks if the preceding operand does not match any value in the results of the Search-based statement that is defined by the operand. The condition is true if the result set does not contain a value that is equal to the preceding operand. Equivalent to SQL statement NOT IN(SELECT FROM ).

member.name: T:PX.Data.BQL.BqlOperand`2.IsIn`1
member.summary: Checks if the preceding operand matches any value in the array returned by the operand that should be the Required or Optional BQL parameter with a specified field name. The condition is true if the preceding operand is equal to a value from the array. Equivalent to the SQL operator IN. The In operator is used to replace multiple OR conditions in a BQL statement.

member.name: T:PX.Data.BQL.BqlOperand`2.IsNotIn`1
member.summary: Checks if the preceding operand does not match any value in the array returned by the operand that should be the Required or Optional BQL parameter with a specified field name. The condition is true if the array does not contain a value that is equal to the preceding operand. Equivalent to SQL operator NOT IN.

member.name: T:PX.Data.BQL.BqlOperand`2.IsIn`2
member.summary: Checks if the specified field value matches any value in the list of constants defined by the operand. The condition is true if the field value is equal to a value from the list.

member.name: T:PX.Data.BQL.BqlOperand`2.IsNotIn`2
member.summary: Checks if the specified field value does not match a value in the list of constants defined by the operand. The condition is true if the field value is not present in the list.

member.name: T:PX.Data.BQL.BqlOperand`2.IsInSequence`1
member.summary: Checks if the specified field value matches any value in the list of constants defined by the operand. The condition is true if the field value is equal to a value from the list.

member.name: T:PX.Data.BQL.BqlOperand`2.IsNotInSequence`1
member.summary: Checks if the specified field value does not match a value in the list of constants defined by the operand. The condition is true if the field value is not present in the list.

code.title: Example
code.description: The code below shows the definition of a DAC field. The NotEqual<> class is used in the BQL command that retrieves the data records that can be selected in the lookup control.

example.code: [PXDBString(10, IsUnicode = true, IsKey = true, InputMask = ">CCCCCCCCCCCCCCC")] [PXDefault()] [PXUIField(DisplayName = "Discount Code")] [PXSelector(typeof( Search<APDiscount.discountID, Where<APDiscount.type, NotEqual<DiscountType.LineDiscount>>>))] public virtual String DiscountID { get; set; }

member.summary: Checks if the preceding operand is greater than Operand.
member.typeparam: The operand to compare to.

member.name: T:PX.Data.Less`1
member.summary: Checks if the preceding operand is less than Operand.
member.typeparam: The operand to compare to.

code.title: Example
code.description: The code below creates a dynamic data view that selects financial periods satifying the condition. The corresponding SQL code is also shown.

example.code: PXSelectBase selectperiod = new PXSelect<FinPeriod, Where<FinPeriod.startDate, Less<FinPeriod.endDate>, And<FinPeriod.finYear, Equal<Required<FinPeriod.finYear>>>>, OrderBy<Desc<FinPeriod.periodNbr>>>(this);
SELECT * FROM FinPeriod WHERE ( FinPeriod.StartDate < FinPeriod.EndDate AND FinPeriod.FinYear = [value] ) ORDER BY FinPeriod.PeriodNbr DESC

member.name: T:PX.Data.GreaterEqual`1
member.summary: Checks if the preceding operand is greater or equal to Operand.
member.typeparam: The operand to compare to.

member.name: T:PX.Data.LessEqual`1
member.summary: Checks if the preceding operand is less or equal to Operand.
member.typeparam: The operand to compare to.

member.name: T:PX.Data.Like`1
member.summary: Compares the preceding operand with the pattern specified in Operand. Equivalent to the SQL operator LIKE.
member.typeparam: The operand to compare to.
member.remarks: Operand should have a wildcard string value in which the sign "%" is used to substitute missing letters. For example, "%land%" will be matched by "Iceland" and "Laplandia".

code.title: Example
code.description: The code below selects and iterates over accounts whose account IDs match the provided wildcard.

member.name: T:PX.Data.NotLike`1
member.summary: Checks if the preceding operand does not match the pattern specified in Operand. Equivalent to SQL operator NOT LIKE.
member.typeparam: The operand to compare to.

code.title: Example
code.description: The code below shows the definition of a DAC field. The PXSelector attribute configures the lookup control that will represent the PageID field in the UI.

example.code: [PXDBGuid(IsKey = true)] [PXSelector(typeof(Search2<SimpleWikiPage.pageID, InnerJoin<WikiDescriptor, On<WikiDescriptor.pageID, Equal<SimpleWikiPage.wikiID>>>, Where<WikiDescriptor.articleType, Equal<WikiArticleTypeAttribute.kb>, And<SimpleWikiPage.name, NotLike<GenTemplateLeftLike>, And<SimpleWikiPage.name, NotLike<TemplateLeftLike>, And<SimpleWikiPage.name, NotLike<ContainerTemplateLeftLike>>>>>>))] public virtual Guid? PageID { get; set; }

member.name: T:PX.Data.StartsWith`1
member.summary: Checks if the preceding string operand starts with the string. Equivalent to SQL operator LIKE @P0 + '%'.

member.name: T:PX.Data.EndsWith`1
member.summary: Checks if the preceding string operand ends with the string. Equivalent to SQL operator LIKE '%' + @P0.

member.name: T:PX.Data.Contains`1
member.summary: Checks if the preceding string operand contains the string. Equivalent to SQL operator LIKE '%' + @P0 + '%'.

member.name: T:PX.Data.Between`2
member.summary: Checks if the value of the preceding operand falls between the values of Operand1 and Operand2. Equivalent to SQL operator BETWEEN.
member.typeparam: The beginning of the range.
The end of the range.

code.title: Example
code.description: The code below shows a data view that uses Between<> in the conditional expression and the SQL query corresponding to the data view.

example.code: SELECT * FROM TaxRev WHERE ( TaxRev.TaxID = [tran.TaxID value] AND TaxRev.TaxType = [tran.TaxType value] AND TaxRev.OutDated = CONVERT(bit, 0) AND [tran.TranDate value] BETWEEN TaxRev.StartDate AND TaxRev.EndDate )

member.name: T:PX.Data.NotBetween`2
member.summary: Checks if the value of the preceding operand does not fall between the values of Operand1 and Operand2. Equivalent to SQL operator NOT BETWEEN.
member.typeparam: The beginning of the range.
The end of the range.

member.name: T:PX.Data.IsNull
member.summary: Checks if the preceding field is null. Equivalent to SQL operator IS NULL.

member.name: T:PX.Data.IsNotNull
member.summary: Checks if the preceding field is not null. Results in true for data records with this field containing a value. Equivalent to SQL operator IS NOT NULL.

code.title: Example
code.description: The code below shows the data view defined in a graph and the corresponding SQL query.

example.code: SELECT * FROM APTran WHERE ( APTran.TranType = [apdoc.DocType value] AND APTran.RefNbr = [apdoc.RefNbr value] AND APTran.Box1099 IS NOT NULL )

member.name: T:PX.Data.Constant`1
member.summary: The base class for BQL constants.
member.typeparam: The data type of the constant.
member.remarks: To define a custom constant in the application, derive a class from Constant<>. Specify constant's type in the ConstType type parameter and implement the constructor. The constructor should inherit base class constructor and provide the constant's actual value in its argument.

code.title: Example
code.description: The predefined constant Zero represents integer 0 and is not suitable for comparison with decimal values. The application should define a custom constant for decimal zero, deriving it from Constant<Decimal> as the following code shows.

code.title: Example2
code.description: This constant can be used in BQL statements in the following way:

example.code: PXSelect<Table, Where<Table.decimalField, Greater<decimal_0>>>

code.title: Example3
code.description: This BQL statement is translated into the following SQL query:

example.code: SELECT * FROM Table WHERE Table.DecimalField > .0

member.name: T:PX.Data.Null
member.summary: The null value used in Switch clauses as a default value. Don't use this constant for checking fields for null value use the IsNull and IsNotNull classes instead.

code.title: Example
code.description: The code below shows the usage of the Null class in a formula added to the definition of a DAC field.

example.code: [PXDBInt()] [PXDefault(PersistingCheck = PXPersistingCheck.Nothing)] [PXUIField(DisplayName = "Labor Item", Required = false)] [PXFormula( typeof(Switch< Case<Where<perItemBilling, Equal<BillingTypeListAttribute.perActivity>>, Null>, Current<labourItemID>>))] public virtual Int32? LabourItemID { get; set; }

member.name: T:PX.Data.CurrentValue`1
member.summary: Equivalent to the Current parameter, but is used in the PXProjection attribute.
member.typeparam: The field whose current value is inserted.
member.example:
The code below shows the definition of a DAC field.
[PXDBCalced( typeof(Left<INSubItem.subItemCD, CurrentValue<Dimension.segments>>), typeof(string))] public override string SubItemCD { get; set; }

member.name: T:PX.Data.SavedStringValue`1
member.summary: Includes in a BQL command a previously saved string value. The class can be used if current cannot be accessed easily. For example, the class can be used in some attributes. The value must be saved in the corresponded slot using PXContext.SetSlot function.
member.typeparam: The field whose current value is recovered.
member.example:
The code below shows the definition of a DAC field.
[PXDBCalced( typeof(Left<INSubItem.subItemCD, CurrentValue<Dimension.segments>>), typeof(string))] public override string SubItemCD { get; set; }

member.name: T:PX.Data.CurrentMatch`1
member.summary: Matches only the data records the specified user has access rights for. Equivalent to Match<Field>, but is used in the PXProjection attribute.
member.typeparam: The field holding the user name.

member.name: T:PX.Data.CurrentMatch`2
member.summary: Matches only the data records the specified user has access rights for. The condition is applied to the data records of the table set with Table. Equivalent to Match<Table, Field>, but is used in the PXProjection attribute.
member.typeparam: The DAC whose data records are cheched by the condition.
The field holding the user name.

member.name: T:PX.Data.Now
member.summary: Current UTC time.

code.title: Example
code.description: The code below shows a data view that select EPActivity data records with the ReminderDate field less or equal than the current date, and the corresponding SQL query.

member.name: T:PX.Data.True
member.summary: The true value for comparing with boolean fields. In translation to SQL corresponds to CONVERT(BIT, 1).

code.title: Example
code.description: The code below iterates over the APInvoice data records retrieved by using the static Select(...) method. The SQL query corresponding to the BQL query is given below.

example.code: foreach (APInvoice rec in PXSelect<APInvoice, Where<APInvoice.openDoc, Equal<True>, And2<Where<APInvoice.released, Equal<True>, Or<APInvoice.prebooked,Equal<True>>>>>.Select(this)) { ... }
SELECT * FROM APInvoice WHERE APInvoice.OpenDoc = CONVERT(BIT, 1) AND ( APInvoice.Released = CONVERT(BIT, 1) OR APInvoice.Prebooked = CONVERT(BIT, 1) )

member.name: T:PX.Data.FreeText`3
member.summary: This class is used to find all records for which the value of the specified field matches the meaning (not just the exact wording) of the text that is specified in the operand.
member.typeparam: Specifies the field in which the text specified by Operand should be found.
Specifies the text to be found.
Specifies the key field.
member.remarks: The class can be used in the Where clause.

code.title: Example
code.description: For example, the following statement illustrates the use of the FreeText function.

example.code: PXSelect<SearchIndex, Where< FreeText< SearchIndex.content, Required<SearchIndex.content>, SearchIndex.indexID>>>

code.title: Example2
code.description: This statement is converted to the following SQL statement, where search_value is the value that is specified with the Required parameter.

example.code: SELECT * FROM SearchIndex INNER JOIN FREETEXTTABLE(SearchIndex, SearchIndex.content, search_value) AS ftt_SearchIndex ON ftt_SearchIndex.Key = SearchIndex.indexID

member.name: T:PX.Data.FreeText`4
member.summary: This class is used to find all records for which the value of the specified field matches the meaning (not just the exact wording) of the text that is specified in the operand. The returned table contains the specified number of the highest-ranked matches.
member.typeparam: Specifies the text to be found.
Specifies the field in which the text specified by Operand should be found.
Specifies the key field.
member.remarks: The class can be used in the Where clause.

code.title: Example
code.description: For example, the following statement illustrates the use of the FreeText function.

example.code: PXSelect<SearchIndex, Where< Contains< SearchIndex.content, Required<SearchIndex.content>, SearchIndex.indexID, Argument<int?>>>>

code.title: Example2
code.description: This statement is converted to the following SQL statement, where search_value is the value that is specified with the Required parameter, and number_of_records is the value that is specified with the Argument parameter.

example.code: SELECT * FROM SearchIndex INNER JOIN FREETEXTTABLE(SearchIndex, SearchIndex.content, search_value, number_of_records) AS ftt_SearchIndex ON ftt_SearchIndex.Key = SearchIndex.indexID

member.name: T:PX.Data.Contains`3

summary.para: This function is used to find all records for which the value of the specified field contains the text that is specified in the operand.

member.typeparam: Specifies the field in which the text specified by Operand should be found.
Specifies the text to be found.
Specifies the key field.
member.remarks: By using full-text search functions, you can perform a full-text search on full-text indexed columns containing character-based data types. The full-text search functions can be used in the Where clause.

code.title: Example
code.description: The following statement illustrates the use of the Contains function. This statement is converted to the following SQL statement, where search_value is the value that is specified with the Required parameter.

example.code: PXSelect<SearchIndex, Where< Contains< SearchIndex.content, Required<SearchIndex.content>, SearchIndex.indexID>>>
SELECT * FROM SearchIndex INNER JOIN CONTAINSTABLE(SearchIndex, SearchIndex.content, search_value) AS ftt_SearchIndex ON ftt_SearchIndex.Key = SearchIndex.indexID

member.name: T:PX.Data.Contains`4
member.summary: The function is used to find all records for which the value of the specified field contains the text that is specified in the operand. The returned table contains the specified number of the highest-ranked matches. e
member.typeparam: Specifies the field in which the text specified by Operand should be found.
Specifies the text to be found.
Specifies the key field.
member.remarks: The class can be used in the Where clause.

code.title: Example
code.description: For example, the following statement illustrates the use of the Contains function.

example.code: PXSelect<SearchIndex, Where< Contains< SearchIndex.content, Required<SearchIndex.content>, SearchIndex.indexID, Argument<int?>>>>

code.title: Example2
code.description: This statement is converted to the following SQL statement, where search_value is the value that is specified with the Required parameter, and number_of_records is the value that is specified with the Argument parameter.

example.code: SELECT * FROM SearchIndex INNER JOIN CONTAINSTABLE(SearchIndex, SearchIndex.content, search_value, number_of_records) AS ftt_SearchIndex ON ftt_SearchIndex.Key = SearchIndex.indexID

member.name: T:PX.Data.Abs`1
member.summary: Returns module number.
member.typeparam: A field, constant, or function.

code.title: Example
code.description: The code below shows the usage of the Abs<> class in the calculation of a DAC field through the %PXDBCalced:PXDBCalcedAttribute% attribute.

example.code: [PXDefault(TypeCode.Decimal, "0.0")] [PXDBCalced( typeof(Switch< Case<Where<LandedCostTran.aPDocType, Equal<APDocType.debitAdj>>, Abs<LandedCostTran.curyLCAPAmount>>, LandedCostTran.curyLCAPAmount>), typeof(Decimal))] [PXUIField(DisplayName = "Amount")] public virtual Decimal? CuryLCAPEffAmount { get; set; }

member.name: T:PX.Data.Add`2
member.summary: Returns the sum of the Operand1 and Operand2 values.
member.typeparam: A field, constant, or function.
A field, constant, or function.

code.title: Example
code.description: The following code shows a DAC field definition, which is calculated by the formula.

example.code: [PXCurrency(typeof(ARPayment.curyInfoID), typeof(ARPayment.unappliedBal))] [PXUIField(DisplayName = "Available Balance", Visibility = PXUIVisibility.Visible, Enabled = false)] [PXFormula(typeof(Sub<ARPayment.curyDocBal, Add<ARPayment.curyApplAmt, ARPayment.curySOApplAmt>>))] public virtual Decimal? CuryUnappliedBal { ... }

code.title: Example2
code.description: Below you can see the corresponding SQL query from the example above.

example.code: (ARPayment.CuryDocBal - (ARPayment.CuryApplAmt + ARPayment.CurySOApplAmt))

member.name: T:PX.Data.Plus`2
member.summary: Deprecated. Use the Add<Operand1,Operand2> class instead.

member.name: T:PX.Data.BitwiseAnd`2
member.summary: Returns the binary AND of Operand1 and Operand2.

member.name: T:PX.Data.Case`2
member.summary: Specifies a condition that should be evaluated in the Switch clause, and the expression, which should be returned if the condition is satisfied.
member.typeparam: The conditional expression, the Where class.
The value specified as field, constant, or function.
member.remarks: The condition is set by the Where clause. In the translation to SQL, Case is replaced with WHEN [conditions] THEN [expression].

code.title: Example
code.description: The code below shows the definition of a DAC field calculated at run time.

example.code: [PXDBInt] [PXUIField(DisplayName = "Time")] [PXFormula(typeof( Switch< Case<Where<EPActivity.trackTime, NotEqual<True>>, int0>, EPActivity.timeSpent>))] public virtual Int32? TimeSpent { ... }

member.name: T:PX.Data.Case`3
member.summary: Specifies a single condition to evaluate in the Switch clause and the expression to return if the condition is satisfied, and allows attaching more Case clauses.
member.typeparam: The conditional expression, the Where class.
The value specified as field, constant, or function.
The next Case clause.
member.example:
The code below shows the usage of Switch and Case classes in OrderBy. Because of the expression with Switch, the rows with the FABookBalance.UpdateGL field equal to false will be placed before the rows with FABookBalance.UpdateGL equal to true.
[PXDefault(typeof( Search2<FinPeriod.finPeriodID, InnerJoin<FABookBalance, On<FABookBalance.deprFromPeriod, LessEqual<FinPeriod.finPeriodID>>>, Where<FABookBalance.assetID, Equal<Current<FixedAsset.assetID>>, And<FinPeriod.endDate, Greater<FinPeriod.startDate>>>, OrderBy<Asc<Switch<Case<Where<FABookBalance.updateGL, Equal<True>>, int1>, int0>, Desc<FinPeriod.finPeriodID>>>>))] public virtual string PeriodID { ... }

member.name: T:PX.Data.Div`2
member.summary: Returns the division of Operand1 and Operand2
member.typeparam: A field, constant, or function.
A field, constant, or function.

code.title: Example
code.description: The code below shows the definition of a DAC field and the SQL expression that is inserted into the query to get the value for the DAC field.

example.code: [PXDBCalced( typeof(Switch<Case<Where<ARTran.qty, NotEqual<decimal0>>, Div<ARTran.tranCost, ARTran.qty>>, decimal0>), typeof(Decimal))] [PXDefault(TypeCode.Decimal, "0.0")] public virtual Decimal? UnitCost { get; set; }
CASE WHEN ARTran.Qty != 10m THEN ARTran.TranCost / ARTran.Qty ELSE 10m END

member.name: T:PX.Data.IsNull`2

A field, constant, or function.

code.title: Example
code.description: The code below shows a part of a DAC field definition. The formula here sets the CuryRUTROTUndistributedAmt field at run time to the difference of the ARInvoice.CuryRUTROTTotalAmt and ARInvoice.CuryRUTROTTotalAmt values and to decimal zero if any of these values is null.

example.code: [PXFormula(typeof( IsNull<Sub<ARInvoice.curyRUTROTTotalAmt, ARInvoice.curyRUTROTDistributedAmt>, decimal0>))] public virtual decimal? CuryRUTROTUndistributedAmt { get; set; }

member.summary: Returns the multiplication of Operand1 by Operand2.

member.name: T:PX.Data.NullIf`2
member.summary: Returns null if Operand1 equals Operand2 and returns Operand1 if the two expression are not equal. Equivalent to SQL function NULLIF.
member.typeparam: A field, constant, or function.
A field, constant, or function.

code.title: Example
code.description: The code below shows part of the definition of a DAC field. The NullIf<,> class is used in the formula to prevent deletion by zero. If the APTran.qty equals zero, the formula returns null, so the CuryDiscCost value is null.

example.code: [PXFormula(typeof( Div<Sub<APTran.curyTranAmt, APTran.curyDiscAmt>, NullIf<APTran.qty, decimal0>>))] [PXUIField(DisplayName = "Disc. Unit Cost", Enabled = false, Visible = false)] public virtual Decimal? CuryDiscCost { get; set; }

member.name: T:PX.Data.Switch`2
member.summary: Evaluates conditions and returns one of multiple possible values or the default value if none of the conditions is satisfied. Equivalent to SQL CASE-ELSE expression. Pairs condition-value are specified via the Case clause.
member.typeparam: Pairs condition-value specified via the Case class.
The default value as field, constant, or function.

code.title: Example
code.description: The code below shows the definition of a DAC field and the SQL expression inserted into the query to calculate the field value.

example.code: [PXDBCalced( typeof(Switch< Case<Where<APInvoice.paySel, Equal<boolTrue>>, APInvoice.payDate>, APInvoice.dueDate>), typeof(DateTime))] public virtual DateTime? EstPayDate { ... }
CASE WHEN APInvoice.PaySel = 1 THEN APInvoice.PayDate ELSE 0 END

member.name: T:PX.Data.Switch`1
member.summary: Evaluates conditions and returns one of multiple possible values. Equivalent to SQL CASE expression without the ELSE expression. The condition-value pairs are specified via the Case clause.
member.typeparam: Pairs condition-value specified via the Case class.
member.remarks: The Switch clause can be used as Operand in classes such as Where ad OrderBy.

code.title: Example
code.description: The code below shows the definition of a DAC field calculated at run time.

example.code: [PXFormula(typeof(Switch< Case<Where<EPActivity.priority, Equal<int0>>, EPActivity.priorityIcon.low, Case<Where<EPActivity.priority, Equal<int2>>, EPActivity.priorityIcon.high>>>))] public virtual String PriorityIcon { get; set; }

code.title: Example2
code.description: This is translated into:

example.code: CASE WHEN Table.Field1 < Table.Field2 THEN Table.Field3 WHEN Table.Field1 = Table.Field2 THEN Table.Field4 WHEN Table.Field1 > Table.Field2 THEN Table.Field5 END

member.name: T:PX.Data.In`1
member.summary: Checks if the preceding operand matches any value in the array returned by the operand that should be the Required or Optional BQL parameter with a specified field name. The condition is true if the preceding operand is equal to a value from the array. Equivalent to the SQL operator IN. The In operator is used to replace multiple OR conditions in a BQL statement.

member.name: T:PX.Data.NotIn`1
member.summary: Checks if the preceding operand does not match any value in the array returned by the operand that should be the Required or Optional BQL parameter with a specified field name. The condition is true if the array does not contain a value that is equal to the preceding operand. Equivalent to SQL operator NOT IN.

member.name: T:PX.Data.In2`1
member.summary: Checks if the preceding operand matches any value in the results of the Search-based statement that is defined by the operand. The condition is true if the preceding operand is equal to a value from the result set. Equivalent to SQL statement IN(SELECT ... FROM ...).

member.name: T:PX.Data.NotIn2`1
member.summary: Checks if the preceding operand does not match any value in the results of the Search-based statement that is defined by the operand. The condition is true if the Search<> result set does not contain a value that is equal to the preceding operand.

member.name: T:PX.Data.In3`4
member.summary: Checks if the specified field value matches any value in the list of constants defined by the operand. The list can contain from two to four constants. The condition is true if the field value is equal to a value from the list. Equivalent to (... OR ... OR ... OR ...) statement.

member.name: T:PX.Data.On`1
member.summary: Specifies the joining condition for a JOIN clause. Corresponds to SQL keyword ON.
member.typeparam: The conditional expression, the Not, Where, or Where2 class.

code.title: Example
code.description: Below is an example of a data view with On and the corresponding SQL query.

example.code: SELECT * FROM Table1 INNER JOIN Table2 ON NOT (Table2.Field2 = Table1.Field1)

member.name: T:PX.Data.On`2
member.summary: Specifies a single joining condition for a JOIN clause. Corresponds to SQL keyword ON.
member.typeparam: The compared operand.
The comparison operator.

code.title: Example
code.description: Below is an example of a data view with On and the corresponding SQL query.

example.code: PXSelectJoin<Table1, InnerJoin<Table2, On<Table2.field2, Equal<Table1.field1>>>> records;
SELECT * FROM Table1 INNER JOIN Table2 ON Table2.Field2 = Table1.Field1

member.name: T:PX.Data.On`3
member.summary: Specifies a single joining condition for a JOIN clause and allows continuing the chain of conditions using a logical operator. Corresponds to SQL keyword ON.
member.typeparam: The compared operand.
The comparison operator.
The next conditional expression.

code.title: Example
code.description: Below is an example of a data view with On and the corresponding SQL query.

example.code: PXSelectJoin<Table1, InnerJoin<Table2, On<Table2.field1, Equal<Table1.field2>, And<Table2.field3, Equal<Table1.field4>>>>> records;
SELECT * FROM Table1 INNER JOIN Table2 ON Table2.Field1 = Table1.Field2 AND Table2.Field3 = Table1.Field4

member.name: T:PX.Data.On2`2
member.summary: Specifies the joining condition for a JOIN clause and allows continuing the chain of conditions using a logical operator. Corresponds to SQL keyword ON.
member.typeparam: The conditional expression, the Not, Where, or Where2 class.
The next conditional expression.

code.title: Example
code.description: The code below selects ARRegister data records for the current customer and joins ARAdjust data records. The second code sample shows the corresponding SQL query.

example.code: PXResultset<ARRegister> docs = PXSelectJoin<ARRegister, InnerJoin<ARAdjust, On2< Where<ARAdjust.adjgDocType, Equal<ARRegister.docType>, Or<ARAdjust.adjgDocType, Equal<ARDocType.payment>, And<ARRegister.docType, Equal<ARDocType.voidPayment>, Or<ARAdjust.adjgDocType, Equal<ARDocType.prepayment>, And<ARRegister.docType, Equal<ARDocType.voidPayment>>>>>>, And<ARAdjust.adjgRefNbr, Equal<ARRegister.refNbr>>>>, Where<ARRegister.customerID, Equal<Current<Customer.bAccountID>>>>.Select(this);

SELECT * FROM ARRegister INNER JOIN ARAdjust ON ( ( ARAdjust.AdjgDocType = ARRegister.DocType OR ARAdjust.AdjgDocType = "PMT" AND ARRegister.DocType = "RPM" OR ARAdjust.AdjgDocType = "PPM" AND ARRegister.DocType = "RPM" ) AND ARAdjust.AdjgRefNbr = ARRegister.RefNbr ) WHERE ARRegister.CustomerID = [current Customer.BAccountID value]

member.name: T:PX.Data.Current`1

summary.para: Inserts the field value from the Current property of the cache. If the Current property is null or the field value is null, the parameter will be replaced by the default value.

member.typeparam: The inserted field value.

code.title: Example
code.description: The code below shows a data view with Current and the corresponding SQL query. Where [value] is the TableID value from the Current property of the PXCache<Table1> object.

example.code: SELECT * FROM Table2 WHERE Table2.TableID = [value]

member.name: T:PX.Data.Current2`1
member.summary: Works similar to Current, but the default value will not be inserted if NULL was passed to the parameter.
member.typeparam: The inserted field value.

summary.para: Replaced by a value passed to the Select() method. The value type should match the type of the field specified as Field.

code.title: Example
code.description: The code below shows a data view and the corresponding SQL query.

example.code: PXResutset<Table> res = new PXSelect<Table1, Where<Table1.field1, Equal<Required<Table1.field1>>>> .Select(this, val);
SELECT * FROM Table1 WHERE Table1.Field1 = [the val variable value]

member.name: T:PX.Data.Optional`1
member.summary: Inserts the Current property value of the cache or the value explicitly passed to the Select() method. In the latter case, the parameter causes raising of the FieldUpdating event for the specified field (which can modify or substitute the value). If the null value is passed or the Current property is null, the default value of the field is inserted.
member.typeparam: The inserted field value.

code.title: Example
code.description: The code below shows a data view and the corresponding SQL query.

example.code: PXResutset<Table1> res = new PXSelect<Table1, Where<Table1.field1, Equal<Optional<Table2.field1>>>> .Select(this, val);
SELECT * FROM Table1 WHERE Table1.Field1 = [value]

member.name: T:PX.Data.Optional2`1
member.summary: Same as Optional, but in case the null value is passed to the parameter, doesn't insert the default value.
member.typeparam: The inserted field value.

member.name: T:PX.Data.Context`1

summary.para: Inserts a Navigation Context value. When you use this parameter, the FieldUpdating event will be triggered for the specified field. This event can modify or substitute the value.

member.typeparam: The field to convert a value passed within context with FieldUpdating event.

code.title: Example
code.description: In the following example a new value (val) will be assigned to the Field1.

example.code: PXResutset<Table1> res = new PXSelect<Table1, Where<Table1.field1, Equal<Context<Table2.field1>>>> .Select(this, val);

code.title: Example2
code.description: The expression above will be translated into the following SQL query.

example.code: SELECT * FROM Table1 WHERE Table1.Field1 = [value]

member.name: T:PX.Data.Argument`1

summary.para: You use this parameter to pass a particular data type value from the UI control to the associated data view.

member.typeparam: A data type.

code.title: Example
code.description: The example below shows a data view that contains all the records from the Field1 that are greater than the argument, the value of which is provided in the Select method.

code.title: Example2
code.description: The expression above will be translated into the following SQL query.

example.code: SELECT * FROM Table1 WHERE Table1.Field1 > 5

member.name: T:PX.Data.Coalesce`2
member.summary: Retrieves a value using Search1 or, if it returns null, Search2.
member.typeparam: The main Search expression.
The additional Search expression.

member.name: T:PX.Data.Search`1
member.summary: Retrieves a field value.
member.typeparam: The DAC field whose value is selected.

code.title: Example
code.description: The code below shows the definition of a DAC field. The Search<> class is used in the PXDefault attribute to specify the field whose value should be used as the default value for the CashCuryID field.

example.code: [PXDBString(5, IsUnicode = true, BqlField = typeof(CashAccount.curyID))] [PXDefault(typeof(Search<Company.baseCuryID>))] [PXUIField(DisplayName = "Cash Account Currency")] public virtual string CashCuryID { get; set; }

member.name: T:PX.Data.Search`2
member.summary: Retrieves a field value, applying filtering.
member.typeparam: The DAC field whose value is selected.
The WHERE clause.

code.title: Example
code.description: The code below shows the definition of a DAC field.

example.code: [PXDBString(10, IsUnicode = true)] [PXUIField(DisplayName = "Payment Method", Visibility = PXUIVisibility.SelectorVisible)] [PXSelector( typeof(Search<PaymentMethod.paymentMethodID, Where<PaymentMethod.useForAP,Equal<True>>>), DescriptionField = typeof(CA.PaymentMethod.descr))] public virtual String PayTypeID { get; set; }

member.name: T:PX.Data.Search`3
member.summary: Retrieves a field from a table, applying filtering and ordering.
member.typeparam: The DAC field whose value is selected.
The WHERE clause.
The ORDER BY clause.

code.title: Example
code.description: The code below shows a part of the DAC field definition. The Search<,,> class is used to specify the source of the default value for the FinPeriodID field.

example.code: [PXDefault(typeof( Search<FinPeriod.finPeriodID, Where<FinPeriod.aPClosed, Equal<False>>, OrderBy<Desc<FinPeriod.finPeriodID>>>))] [PXUIField(DisplayName = "Fin. Period")] public virtual String FinPeriodID { get; set; }

member.name: T:PX.Data.OrderBy`1
member.summary: The clause for specifying how to order the result set of a BQL statetement, equivalent to the SQL clause ORDER BY.
member.typeparam: The fields to sort by, Asc or Desc class.

code.description: An example of a data view with OrderBy and the corresponding SQL query are given below.

example.code: SELECT * FROM Table1 WHERE Table1.Field1 IS NOT NULL ORDER BY Table1.Field1

member.name: T:PX.Data.Asc`1
member.summary: Indication of sorting in ascending order: from the least value to the largest value. The field to order by is specified in the Field type parameter. The clause itself is used as a type parameter in OrderBy.
member.typeparam: The field to sort by.

code.title: Example
code.description: An example of a data view with Asc with one type parameter and the corresponding SQL query are given below.

example.code: SELECT * FROM Table1 WHERE Table1.Field1 IS NOT NULL ORDER BY Table1.Field1

member.name: T:PX.Data.Desc`1
member.summary: Indication of sorting in descending order: from the largest value down to the least value. The field to order by is specified in the Field type parameter. The clause itself is used as a type parameter in OrderBy.
member.typeparam: The field to sort by.

code.title: Example
code.description: An example of a data view with Desc with one type parameter and the corresponding SQL query are given below.

example.code: SELECT * FROM Table1 WHERE Table1.Field2 = Table1.Field1 ORDER BY Table1.Field1 DESC

member.name: T:PX.Data.Asc`2
member.summary: A variant of the Asc clause used to add additional sort expression.
member.typeparam: The field to sort by.
The next field to sort by.

code.title: Example
code.description: An example of a data view with Asc with two type parameters and the corresponding SQL query are given below.

example.code: PXSelect<Table1, Where<Table1.field1, IsNotNull>, OrderBy<Asc<Table1.field1, Desc<Table1.field2>>>> records;
SELECT * FROM Table1 WHERE Table1.Field1 IS NOT NULL ORDER BY Table1.Field1, Table1.Field2 DESC

member.name: T:PX.Data.Desc`2
member.summary: A variant of the Desc clause used to add additional sort expression.
member.typeparam: The field to sort by.
The next field to sort by.

code.title: Example
code.description: An example of a data view with Desc with two type parameters and the corresponding SQL query are given below.

example.code: PXSelect<Table1, Where<Table1.field1, IsNotNull>, OrderBy<Desc<Table1.field1, Asc<Table1.field2>>>> records;
SELECT * FROM Table1 WHERE Table1.Field1 IS NOT NULL ORDER BY Table1.Field1 DESC, Tabl1e.Field2

member.name: T:PX.Data.Not`1

member.typeparam: The unary operator, Where, Where2, or Match class.

public PXSelectJoin<Schedule, LeftJoin<APRegisterAccess, On<APRegisterAccess.scheduleID, Equal<Schedule.scheduleID>, And<APRegisterAccess.scheduled, Equal<boolTrue>, And<Not<Match<APRegisterAccess, Current<AccessInfo.userName>>>>>>>> Schedule_Header;

member.name: T:PX.Data.Not`2
member.summary: Adds logical "not" to a single condition in a BQL statement.
member.typeparam: The compared operand.
The comparison operator.
member.remarks: This Not class can be used to negate a single comparison. In many cases, you can avoid using this class as most of the comparison operators have their negative counterparts (for example, Equal and NotEqual).

member.name: T:PX.Data.Not`3
member.summary: Adds logical "not" to a conditional expression of a BQL statement. In the resulting SQL, the group is preceded with NOT and surrounded by brackets.
member.typeparam: The compared operand.
The comparison operator.
The next conditional expression, And, And2, Or, or Or2 class.

member.name: T:PX.Data.Not2`2

member.typeparam: The unary operator, Where, Where2, or Match class.

member.typeparam: BAccountID to look for the BranchID.

member.name: T:PX.Data.Exists`1

summary.para: Is used to test for the existence of any record in a subquery. The class corresponds to the EXIST SQL statement.

member.typeparam: An appropriate Select<> statement.

example.code: Exists<Select< APTran, Where< APTran.tranType, Equal<TDocTypeField>, And<APTran.refNbr, Equal<TRefNbrField>, And<Where< APTran.pONbr, IsNotNull, Or<APTran.pOLineNbr, IsNotNull, Or<APTran.receiptNbr, IsNotNull, Or<APTran.receiptLineNbr, IsNotNull>>>>>>>>>

code.title: Example2
code.description: The BQL statement above will be translated into the following SQL query.

example.code: EXISTS (SELECT [list of columns] FROM APTran WHERE APTran.TranType = [value of TDocTypeField] AND APTran.RefNbr = [value of TRefNbrField]) AND (APTran.PONbr IS NOT NULL OR APTran.POLineNbr IS NOT NULL OR APTran.ReceiptNbr IS NOT NULL OR APTran.ReceiptLineNbr IS NOT NULL)

member.name: T:PX.Data.CustomPredicate
member.summary: Allows to easily define a shortcut for a custom predicate. Use it if you want to express one predicate through a combination of other ones.

member.name: T:PX.Data.AreSame`2
member.summary: Indicates whether operands are equal or both NULL. If you use a parameter placeholder such as as one of operands, you must pass such parameter value twice! If both operands are parameter placeholders, you must pass their values as shown: operand1, operand2, operand1, operand2

member.name: T:PX.Data.AreDistinct`2
member.summary: Indicates whether operands are not equal or both NULL. If you use a parameter placeholder such as as one of operands, you must pass such parameter value twice! If both operands are parameter placeholders, you must pass their values as shown: operand1, operand2, operand1, operand2

member.name: T:PX.Data.EqualBaseCuryID`1
member.summary: Builds a list of BranchID for a specific BAccountID
member.typeparam: BAccountID to look for the BranchID.

member.name: T:PX.Data.Where`1
member.summary: Specifies an unary operator as the conditional expression for a BQL command.
member.typeparam: The conditional expression, Not or Match class.

code.title: Example
code.description: The code below shows a data view and the corresponding SQL query.

example.code: PXSelect<Table1, Where<Not<Table1.field1, IsNotNull, And<Table1.field2, LessEqual<Table1.field1>>>>> records;
SELECT * FROM Table1 WHERE NOT ( Table1.Field1 IS NOT NULL AND Table1.Field2 <= Table1.Field1 )

member.name: T:PX.Data.Where2`2
member.summary: Specifies a complex conditional expression for a BQL command that typically joins two groups of conditions.
member.typeparam: The first conditional expression.
The logical operator appending the second conditional expression.

code.title: Example
code.description: A filtering expression of the form ((C1 and C2) or (C3 and C4)), where C with a number denotes a single condition, is implemented by the BQL code of the following form:

example.code: Where2<Where<C1, And<C2>>, Or<Where<C3, And<C4>>>>

code.title: Example2
code.description: A full expression of this type may look something like this:

example.code: Where2<Where<Table.field2, Greater<Table.field1> And<Table.field3, Between<Table.field1, Table.field2>>>, Or<Where<Table.field3, IsNull, And<Table.field1, Equal<Table.field2>>>>>

code.title: Example3
code.description: This is translated into:

example.code: WHERE ( Table.Field2 > Table.Field1 AND Table.Field3 BETWEEN Table.Field1 AND Table.Field2 ) OR ( Table.Field3 IS NULL AND Table.Field1 = Table.Field2 )

member.name: T:PX.Data.Where`2
member.summary: Specifies a single filtering condition for a BQL command.
member.typeparam: The compared operand.
The comparison operator.

code.title: Example
code.description: An example of a data view and the corresponding SQL query are given below.

example.code: PXSelect<Table1, Where<Table1.field1, Equal<Table1.field2>>> records;
SELECT * FROM Table1 WHERE Table1.Field1 = Table1.Field2

member.name: T:PX.Data.Where`3
member.summary: Specifies a particular condition in the two first type parameters and attaches one more logical operator (And or Or).
member.typeparam: The compared operand.
The comparison operator.
The next conditional expression.

code.title: Example
code.description: An example of a data view and the corresponding SQL query are given below.

example.code: SELECT * FROM Table1 WHERE Table1.Field1 > Table1.Field2 AND Table.Field3 IS NULL

member.name: T:PX.Data.PXEntryStatus
member.summary: The enumeration that specifies a data record status. A data record status changes as a result of manipulations with the data record: insertion, update, or removal.

remarks.para: The table below shows data record status update depending on different PXCache methods.

member.name: F:PX.Data.PXEntryStatus.Notchanged
member.summary: The data record has not been modified since it was placed in the PXCache object or since the last time the Save action was invoked (triggering execution of BLC's Actions.PressSave()).

member.name: F:PX.Data.PXEntryStatus.Updated
member.summary: The data record has been modified, and the Save action has not been invoked. After the changes are saved to the database, the data record status changes to Notchanged.

member.name: F:PX.Data.PXEntryStatus.Inserted
member.summary: The data record is new and has been added to the PXCache object, and the Save action has not been invoked. After the changes are saved to the database, the data record status changes to Notchanged.

member.name: F:PX.Data.PXEntryStatus.Deleted
member.summary: The data record is not new and has been marked as Deleted within the PXCache object. After the changes are saved, the data record is deleted from the database and removed from the PXCache object.

member.name: F:PX.Data.PXEntryStatus.InsertedDeleted
member.summary: The data record is new and has been added to the PXCache object and then marked as Deleted within the PXCache object. After the changes are saved, the data record is removed from the PXCache object.

member.name: F:PX.Data.PXEntryStatus.Held
member.summary: An Unchanged data record can be marked as Held within the PXCache object to avoid being collected during memory cleanup. Updated, Inserted, Deleted, InsertedDeleted, or Held data records are never collected during memory cleanup. Any Notchanged data record can be removed from the PXCache object during memory cleanup.

member.name: F:PX.Data.PXEntryStatus.Modified
member.summary: This flag is passed to the PXCache<>.SetStatus method to indicate that the data record must be saved. The final status assigned to the data record (whether Inserted or Updated) depends on the initial status of the data record.

places row into collection, returns the same value on success.

member.summary:
Original attributes of a DAC. Cannot be obtained directly.
Are instantiated once for each type on first instantiating of its
Attributes of this level cannot be modified in runtime.

member.name: F:PX.Data.PXAttributeLevel.Cache
member.summary:
Attributes that copied from attributes of , merged with attributes, relevant to the DAC, and then linked to a certain instance.
Are instantiated on every instantiating by copying of attributes.
Attributes of this level can be modified in runtime, usually by calling attributes static methods that have signature corresponding to "AttributeName.SetSomeValue(PXCache sender, object row, SomeType someValue)" and passing null as a second parameter.

member.name: F:PX.Data.PXAttributeLevel.Item
member.summary:
Attributes that copied from attributes of , and then linked to a certain row instance in a .
Are instantiated by copying of attributes at certain data row attributes demanding.
Attributes of this level can be modified in runtime, usually by calling attributes static methods that have signature corresponding to "AttributeName.SetSomeValue(PXCache sender, object row, SomeType someValue)" and passing a certain row as a second parameter.

summary.para: The delegate for the RowUpdating event.

param.name: sender
param.para: Required. The cache object that generated the event.

param.name: e
param.para: Required. The instance of the PXRowUpdatingEventArgs type that holds data for the RowUpdating event.

remarks.para: The RowUpdating event is generated before the data record is actually updated in the PXCache object during an update initiated in either of the following cases:

list.item: In the UI or via Web Service API.

When the following PXCache class methods were invoked:
Update(object)
Update(IDictionary, IDictionary)

remarks.para: The RowUpdating event handler is used to evaluate a data record that is being updated and to cancel the update operation if the data record does not fit the business logic requirements.
The following execution order is used for the RowUpdating event handlers:

list.item: Graph event handlers are executed.
If e.Cancel is false, attribute event handlers are executed.

code.title: Example1a
code.description: According to the naming convention for graph event handlers in Acumatica Framework, the classic event handler must have the following signature.

code.title: Example1b
code.description: The generic event handler must have the following signature.

code.title: Example2a
code.description: The following code uses the classic event handler approach to evaluate the data record that is being updated, cancel the update operation, and show a message box.

code.title: Example2b
code.description: The following code uses the generic event handler approach to evaluate the data record that is being updated, cancel the update operation, and show a message box.

code.title: Example3a
code.description: The following code uses the classic event handler approach to evaluate the data record that is being updated, cancel the update operation, and show the warning or error indication near the input control for one field or multiple fields.

code.title: Example3b
code.description: The following code uses the generic event handler approach to evaluate the data record that is being updated, cancel the update operation, and show the warning or error indication near the input control for one field or multiple fields.

member.name: T:PX.Data.PXRowUpdated

summary.para: The delegate for the RowUpdated event.

member.param: Required. The cache object that raised the event.
Required. The instance of the PXRowUpdatedEventArgs type that holds data for the RowUpdated event.

remarks.para: The RowUpdated event is generated after the data record has been successfully updated in the PXCache object in one of the following cases:

list.item: The update is initiated in the UI or through the Web Service API.

One of the following methods of the PXCache class is invoked:
Update(object)
Update(IDictionary, IDictionary)

div.style: BORDER-TOP: white 2px solid; BORDER-BOTTOM: white 1px solid; MARGIN-TOP: 2px
div.div: The updating of a data record is executed only when there is a data record with the same values of the data access class (DAC) key fields, either in the PXCache object or in the database. Otherwise, the process of inserting the data record is started.

remarks.para: The RowUpdated event handler is used to implement the business logic of the following actions:

list.item: Update of the master data record in a many-to-one relationship
Insertion or update of the detail data records in a one-to-many relationship
Update of the related data record in a one-to-one relationship

remarks.para: The following execution order is used for the RowUpdated event handlers:

list.item: Attribute event handlers are executed.
Graph event handlers are executed.

remarks.para: The RowInserting event is trigged before the new data record is inserted into the PXCache object as a result of one of the following actions:

list.item: Insertion initiated in the UI or through the Web Service API

Invocation of either of the following methods of the PXCache class:
Insert()
Insert(object)
Insert(IDictionary)

remarks.para: The RowInserting event handler is used to perform the following actions:

list.item: Evaluation of the data record that is being inserted
Cancellation of the insertion by throwing an exception
Assignment of the default values to the fields of the data record that is being inserted

remarks.para: The following execution order is used for the RowInserting event handlers:

list.item: Graph event handlers are executed.
If e.Cancel is false, attribute event handlers are executed.

member.name: T:PX.Data.PXRowDeleting
member.summary: The delegate for the RowDeleting event.
member.param: Required. The cache object that raised the event.
Required. The instance of the PXRowDeletingEventArgs type that holds data for the RowDeleting event.

remarks.para: The RowDeleting event is generated for a data record that is being deleted from the PXCache object after its status has been set to Deleted or InsertedDeleted, but the data record can still be reverted to the previous state by canceling the deletion. The status of the data record is set to Deleted or InsertedDeleted as a result of either of the following actions:

list.item: Deletion initiated in the UI or through the Web Service API.

Invocation of the following methods of the PXCache class:
Delete(object)
Delete(IDictionary, IDictionary)

innovasys:widget.innovasys:widgetproperty: When a data record is deleted that has already been stored in the database (and, hence, exists in both the database and the PXCache object), the status of the data record is set to Deleted. For a data record that has not yet been stored in the database but was only inserted in the PXCache object, the status of the data record is set to InsertedDeleted.

remarks.para: The RowDeleting event handler is used to evaluate the data record that is marked as Deleted or InsertedDeleted and cancel the deletion if it is required by the business logic.
The following execution order is used for the RowDeleting event handlers:

list.item: Graph event handlers are executed.
If e.Cancel is false, attribute event handlers are executed.

remarks.para: The RowDeleted event is generated for a data record that is being deleted from the PXCache objectthat is, a data record whose status has been successfully set to Deleted or InsertedDeleted as a result of the following actions:

list.item: Deletion initiated in the UI or through the Web Service API

Invocation of the following methods of the PXCache class:
Delete(object)
Delete(IDictionary, IDictionary)

innovasys:widget.innovasys:widgetproperty: When a data record is deleted that has already been stored in the database (and, hence, exists in both the database and the PXCache object), the status of the data record is set to Deleted. For a data record that has not yet been stored in the database but has only been inserted in the PXCache object, the status of the data record is set to InsertedDeleted.

remarks.para: The RowDeleted event handler is used to implement the business logic of the following actions:

list.item: Deletion of the detail data records in a one-to-many relationship
Update of the master data record in a many-to-one relationship
Deletion or update of the related data record in a one-to-one relationship

remarks.para: The following execution order is used for the RowDeleted event handlers:

list.item: Attribute event handlers are executed.
Graph event handlers are executed.

member.name: T:PX.Data.PXCommandPreparing
member.summary: The delegate for the CommandPreparing event.
member.param: Required. The cache object that raised the event.
Required. The instance of the PXCommandPreparingEventArgs type that contains data for the CommandPreparing event.

remarks.para: The CommandPreparing event is generated each time the Acumatica data access layer prepares a database-specific SQL statement for a SELECT, INSERT, UPDATE, or DELETE operation. This event is raised for every data access class (DAC) field placed in the PXCache object. By using the CommandPreparing event subscriber, you can alter the property values of the PXCommandPreparingEventArgs.FieldDescription object that is used in the generation of an SQL statement.
The CommandPreparing event handler is used in the following cases:

list.item: To exclude a DAC field from a SELECT, INSERT, or UPDATE operation
To replace a DAC field from a SELECT operation with a custom SQL statement
To transform a DAC field value submitted to the server for an INSERT, UPDATE, or DELETE operation

remarks.para: The following execution order is used for the CommandPreparing event handlers:

list.item: Graph event handlers are executed.
If e.Cancel is false, attribute event handlers are executed.

code.description: The following code excludes a DAC field from the UPDATE operation by using the classic event handler approach.

code.title: Example2b
code.description: The following code excludes a DAC field from the UPDATE operation by using the generic event handler approach.

member.name: T:PX.Data.PXRowSelecting

summary.para: The delegate for the RowSelecting event.

member.param: Required. The cache object that raised the event.
Required. The instance of the PXRowSelectingEventArgs type that holds data for the RowSelecting event.

remarks.para: The RowSelecting event is generated for each retrieved data record when the result of a BQL statement is processed. For a BQL statement that contains a JOIN clause, the RowSelecting event is raised for every joined data access class (DAC).
The RowSelecting event handler can be used for the following purposes:

list.item: To calculate DAC field values that are not bound to specific database columns
To modify the logic that converts the database record to the DAC

innovasys:widget.innovasys:widgetproperty: We recommend that you not use RowSelecting event handlers in the application code. However, if you use these event handlers in the application code and you execute additional BQL statements within a RowSelecting event handler, you should use a separate connection scope for the execution. The connection scope that is used to retrieve the data that generated the RowSelecting event is still busy; therefore, no other operations can be performed on this connection scope.

remarks.para: The following execution order is used for the RowSelecting event handlers:

list.item: Graph event handlers are executed.
If e.Cancel is false, attribute event handlers are executed.

member.name: T:PX.Data.PXRowPersisting

summary.para: The delegate for the RowPersisting event.

member.param: Required. The cache object that raised the event.
Required. The instance of the PXRowPersistingEventArgs type that holds data for the RowPersisting event.

remarks.para: The RowPersisting event is generated in the process of committing changes to the database for every data record whose status is Inserted, Updated, or Deleted before the corresponding changes for the data record are committed to the database. The committing of changes to a database is initiated by invoking the Actions.PressSave() method of the business logic controller (BLC). While processing this method, the Acumatica data access layer commits first every inserted data record, then every updated data record, and finally every deleted data record.

innovasys:widget.innovasys:widgetproperty: Avoid executing additional BQL statements in a RowPersisting event handler. When the RowPersisting event is raised, the associated transaction scope is busy saving the changes, and any other operation performed within this transaction scope may cause performance degradation and deadlocks.

remarks.para: The RowPersisting event handler is used to do the following:

list.item: Validate the data record before it has been committed to the database
Cancel the committing of the data record by throwing an exception

remarks.para: The following execution order is used for the RowPersisting event handlers:

list.item: Graph event handlers are executed.
If e.Cancel is false, attribute event handlers are executed.

code.description: The following code uses the classic event handler approach to cancel the operation of committing a data record.

member.name: T:PX.Data.PXRowPersisted

summary.para: The delegate for the RowPersisted event.

member.param: Required. The cache object that raised the event.
Required. The instance of the PXRowPersistedEventArgs type that holds data for the RowPersisted event.

list.item: When the data record has been committed to the database and the status of the transaction scope (indicated in the e.TranStatus field) is Open

When the status of the transaction scope has been changed to Completed, indicating successful committing, or Aborted, indicating that a database error has occurred and changes to the database have been dropped

remarks.para: The Actions.PressSave() method of the business logic controller (graph) initiates the committing of changes to a database. While processing this method, the Acumatica data access layer commits first every inserted data record, then every updated data record, and finally every deleted data record.

innovasys:widget.innovasys:widgetproperty: Avoid executing additional BQL statements in a RowPersisted event handler when the status of the transaction scope is Open. When the RowPersisted event is raised with this status, the associated transaction scope is busy saving the changes, and any other operation performed within this transaction scope may cause performance degradation and deadlocks.

remarks.para: The RowPersisted event handler is used to perform the following actions:

list.item: Retrieval of data generated by the database.

Restoring of data access class (DAC) field values if the status of the transaction scope is Aborted indicating that changes have not been saved. Note that in this case the DAC fields do not revert to any previous state automatically but are left by the Acumatica data access layer in the state they were in before the committing was initiated.
Validation of the data record while committing it to the database.

remarks.para: The following execution order is used for the RowPersisted event handlers:

list.item: Attribute event handlers are executed.
Graph event handlers are executed.

code.description: According to the naming convention for graph event handlers in Acumatica Framework, the classic event handler must have the following signature.

code.title: Example1b
code.description: The generic event handler must have the following signature.

code.title: Example2a
code.description: The following code uses the redefinition of the attribute method to retrieve data generated by the database.

code.title: Example3a
code.description: The following code uses a redefinition of the attribute method to restore the values of a DAC field if the commitment failedresulting in the <tt>Aborted</tt> status of the transaction scope.
